title: JUI-F, nationalists hold rallies against corporate farming, lawlessness in Sindh - Pakistan - DAWN.COM
content:
SUKKUR: The Jamiat Ulema-i-Islam-Fazl (JUI-F), Qaumi Awami Tehreek (QAT) and Awami Tehreek (AT) held separate rallies in different parts of Sindh on Sunday against corporate farming and Sindh government’s failure to fulfill its responsibilities.

The JUI-F rally started from Jamia Masjid, Thull, and ended at Amroti Chowk, where the participants held a sit-in.

Addressing them, JUI-F Jacobabad District Emir Dr A.G. Ansari said that Sindh’s fertile and pricey lands were being doled out to local and foreign firms in the name of corporate farming.

“This is sheer injustice to the province and its people,” he said, and stressed that these lands should, instead, be allotted to landless peasant families. This downtrodden segment must also be provided water, electricity, fertiliser and other farm implements so as to ensure their prosperity, he said.

JUI-F District General Secretary Maulana Saleemullah Brohi, Mufti Abdul Shakoor Khoso, Syed Abdul Basit Shah, Abdul Qadir Channa, Maulana Abdul Waheed Brohi, Haji Mohammad Abbas Banglani, Asadullah Haideri, Maulana Taj Mehmood Bhatti, Advocate Anees-ur-Rehman Soomro, Mansoor Ahmed Rind, Mohammad Ilyas Brohi, Mir Hasan Buriro, Maulana Abdul Razzaq Banglani, Irfan Ali Lohar, Maulana Ghulam Haider Pathan and Sanaullah Khoso also spoke.

They called for immediate measures to restore state’s writ in the dacoit-infested riverine areas of upper Sindh and complete peace in the entire province.

QAT rally in Kandhkot

The Qaumi Awami Tehreek (QAT) held a rally in Kandhkot to condemn federal government’s corporate farming plan, water scarcity in Sindh and provincial government’s failure in restoring law and order in upper Sindh districts.

QAT workers and supporters led by Sajjad Brohi, Mohammad Sachal Malik and Arsalah marched from Tangwani town’s Larro Road to the local bus stand, where they held a demonstration raising slogans against the government and its ‘anti-Sindh’ projects. The leaders strongly condemn the planned ‘auction’ of Sindh’s land to allot the same to corporate sector for farming. They vowed to resist all such plans tooth and nail.

They regretted that the province’s farming community was faced with a severe shortage of water despite availability of the commodity in the system. Hundreds of thousands of acres were turning barren, causing a serious concern to farmers, they said, and demanded immediate stops to resolve this major issue.

The leaders also highlighted the rampant crime in Kandhkot-Kashmore and other districts of upper Sindh, and observed that the law-enforcement agencies had failed to control dacoit gangs, which were continuing to kidnap people for ransom, extorting money from ordinary citizens and honey trapping youths after inviting them to the areas under their control. Such crimes had now become a daily routine, they deplored.

They demanded decisive action against these gangs to liberate the riverine area from outlaws.

AT protest in K.N. Shah

The Awami Tehreek (AT) organised a rally in Khairpur Nathen Shah town of Dadu district on Sunday to condemn corporate farming, drawing of six new canals from the Indus River and “grabbing of Sindh’s lands and other resources” under different plans, says a press release.

The rally started from the town’s community centre and culminated outside the local press club, where the participants held a sit-in, it said.

The rally was led by AT General Secretary Advocate Sajid Hussain Mahesar along with its Dadu District President Advocate Najeeb Mahesar, Atif Mallah, Hadi Dino Khuhro, Bakht Burriro, Advocate Shabbir Khoso, Advocate Dad Magsi, Rashid Bhurgari and others.

They alleged that Sindh’s lands were being “auctioned off” under the corporate farming plan while conspiracies were being hatched to separate Karachi from Sindh. They condemned the recent remarks by an FPCCI leader during his press conference in Karachi to support a division of Sindh to create new provinces. “It’s a ploy to spread unrest in Sindh,” they said, adding that people of Sindh would not tolerate such attacks on the historical city of Karachi.

The leaders also criticised Sindh government for its failure to ensure measures to prevent destruction during monsoon rains and flooding. They alleged that the funds allocated for the repairing and strengthening of Indus embankments and protective bunds had been embezzled by irrigation officials.

They demanded action against corrupt officials.

They noted that while Sindh was facing threat of flood, an artificial shortage of water was being created to destroy its crops.

They also alleged that the PPP government had blocked provision of Sindh’s rightful share in the Indus water.

The party demanded emergency flood protection measures including strengthening of SM Bund, Prio Bund, Kari Mori Bund and MNV drain dykes.

Published in Dawn, August 18th, 2025
